messages.text: FWIW, I don't think it is that important to recognize, it's fairly obvious what is meant with politics here and it should be easy to separate that from the policies the julia community itself implement.

elements.text: FWIW, I don't think it is that important to recognize, it's fairly obvious what is meant with politics here and it should be easy to separate that from the policies the julia community itself implement.

messages.text: It's among the same lines as saying "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance". Technically true, but irrelevant in practice.

elements.text: It's among the same lines as saying "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance". Technically true, but irrelevant in practice.

messages.text:
Yeah I was debating posting that comment. It's probably obvious for you, but for people who never think about politics that way (me as a teenager,  for instance) I think it's useful.

I'm aware that I am coming dangerously close to the edge of the "no politics" line here, but I also want to say that the statement "it is important to recognize that not allowing intolerant people is a limit of tolerance" is not the same. Discussing politics benefits marginalized people who stand to liberate themselves from changing the current politics.

So what I mean is, banning "politics" is really an implicit endorsement of the status quo and the people that benefit from maintaining it. If that is obvious to you, great, but I don't think it is for everyone.

elements.text:

Discussing politics benefits marginalized people who stand to liberate themselves from changing the current politics.

So what I mean is, banning "politics" is really an implicit endorsement of the status quo and the people that benefit from maintaining it. If that is obvious to you, great, but I don't think it is for everyone.

messages.text:
The reason this slack community has policies against political discussion is that the discussions that were happening were becoming increasingly unproductive, nasty and unwelcoming. 

The discussions happening had very little if any benefit to the wider world, but had a palpably negative effect on the health of the community and how welcoming it was to new members.

elements.text:
The reason this slack community has policies against political discussion is that the discussions that were happening were becoming increasingly unproductive, nasty and unwelcoming. 

The discussions happening had very little if any benefit to the wider world, but had a palpably negative effect on the health of the community and how welcoming it was to new members.

messages.text: There's a very specific kind of "politics" that I (personally) don't care for here, not least of which because I have no influence over it: US/any kind of government related politics. Not wanting to talk about things I can't influence at all is not the same as endorsing them.

elements.text: There's a very specific kind of "politics" that I (personally) don't care for here, not least of which because I have no influence over it: US/any kind of government related politics. Not wanting to talk about things I can't influence at all is not the same as endorsing them.

messages.text: "Politics" as it relates to how we, as a community, want to do things for us, is obviously not the in the same vein here - that doesn't mean that we have to bring in that other kind of politics though.

elements.text: "Politics" as it relates to how we, as a community, want to do things for us, is obviously not the in the same vein here - that doesn't mean that we have to bring in that other kind of politics though.

did not properly characterize my comment in his reply.

messages.text: Well, no one is suggesting that you cannot discuss politics outside of the Julia platforms. It's not like the policy means that Kristoffer cannot endorse Trump on twitter for example. It just means that "our" (collectively as Julia users) slack/discourse is not the place to do it.

attachments.text: Hello all! ¡Saludos banda! I will be giving a brief 20 min-ish talk tomorrow in Spanish called “Considering Julia”. It will be in Spanish, the link is below. I will be pre-recording a longer version (á la JuliaCon) so that I can talk about the things I want without feeling rushed :smiley: This was in part facilitated by @categulario (not yet here) and @xalapacode, a Mexican local coding org. I will post a link to the youtube recording here once I’m done.

messages.text: This message was deleted.

I'm afraid the replies to the hackernews comment (in the 1.6 release post) pointing out julia is not top on the list in <https://github.com/kostya/benchmarks> weren't entirely accurate... Too often benchmarks with questionable julia timings include compilation time, but in this case the benchmark is reasonably fair (timing starts halfway in a function by sending some message through a socket, and sometimes a verification test is run before the benchmark). I (and some others) jumped a bit too quickly to the conclusion that the benchmark was unfair/skew, and one comment which correctly points that out got downvoted to oblivion :sweat_smile:

elements.text: We are live:

messages.text: <@U67461GUB>, i just want to mention that ML is not the same as autodiff. gradient heuristic employed in neural networks or deeplearning for prediction or classification is just one of the many techniques in machine learning. for tabular data which are common datasets in ML, autodiff heuristics are always beaten by SVM or Ensemble methods such as xgboost or randomforest. a lot of ML problems are tabular data so i just want to correct the notion that ML is equivalent to autodiff and by having autodiff part of julia language implies it is solving much of ML. a lot of optimization problems are not differentiable too and can be addressed better by gradient-free methods. great talk by the way but i find the talk on autodiff implying that all ML problems to be solvable by autodiff as not right. model selection is important in ML and gradient method is just one of the hundreds of ML methods. it is not always the case that gradient method will be the optimal solution to many ML problems. i don’t want people to think that whenever they have a prediction or classification task, they will not try other ML models and just use gradient-based or autodiff-based algo such as ANN or deeplearning. please do model selection by trying other ML models instead of just one. this is a basic principle in ML modeling: perform model selection, and hyperparameter optimization later... and of course there is information criterion to be aware of in modeling too. autodiff solution for ML is an oversimplification of what the real challenge in ML modeling. autodiff has tendency to either overfit or underfit the solution because it is a greedy heuristic and hard to optimize due to its large number of parameters and very sensitive to its initial parameters.

elements.text: , i just want to mention that ML is not the same as autodiff. gradient heuristic employed in neural networks or deeplearning for prediction or classification is just one of the many techniques in machine learning. for tabular data which are common datasets in ML, autodiff heuristics are always beaten by SVM or Ensemble methods such as xgboost or randomforest. a lot of ML problems are tabular data so i just want to correct the notion that ML is equivalent to autodiff and by having autodiff part of julia language implies it is solving much of ML. a lot of optimization problems are not differentiable too and can be addressed better by gradient-free methods. great talk by the way but i find the talk on autodiff implying that all ML problems to be solvable by autodiff as not right. model selection is important in ML and gradient method is just one of the hundreds of ML methods. it is not always the case that gradient method will be the optimal solution to many ML problems. i don’t want people to think that whenever they have a prediction or classification task, they will not try other ML models and just use gradient-based or autodiff-based algo such as ANN or deeplearning. please do model selection by trying other ML models instead of just one. this is a basic principle in ML modeling: perform model selection, and hyperparameter optimization later... and of course there is information criterion to be aware of in modeling too. autodiff solution for ML is an oversimplification of what the real challenge in ML modeling. autodiff has tendency to either overfit or underfit the solution because it is a greedy heuristic and hard to optimize due to its large number of parameters and very sensitive to its initial parameters.

messages.text: For most of the rest, bayesian ML. If you're doing continuous parameters, again that uses autodiff

messages.text: real world dataset features are not always continuous. and even if it can be attacked by autodiff, it doesn’t follow it is the optimal model. model selection is very critical. no matter how much you optimize the hyperparams of a model which is not intrinsically optimal, it is just waste. not all problems can be solved by a single model. and gradient heuristics are prone to local optima. they are hill-climbing methods or greedy methods. as an ML modeler, you should be unbiased about what model to use. you have to start with zero assumption which model is optimal and try several of them. if you know the distribution, you can basically pick the right model. there are many ML models that are based on certain distribution of data. you should be agnostic in modeling and treat each model to be a potential solution. all models are wrong but some are useful. you have to try several of them to be fair. just look at the kaggle datasets with tabular data and check which models are winning.

elements.text: real world dataset features are not always continuous. and even if it can be attacked by autodiff, it doesn’t follow it is the optimal model. model selection is very critical. no matter how much you optimize the hyperparams of a model which is not intrinsically optimal, it is just waste. not all problems can be solved by a single model. and gradient heuristics are prone to local optima. they are hill-climbing methods or greedy methods. as an ML modeler, you should be unbiased about what model to use. you have to start with zero assumption which model is optimal and try several of them. if you know the distribution, you can basically pick the right model. there are many ML models that are based on certain distribution of data. you should be agnostic in modeling and treat each model to be a potential solution. all models are wrong but some are useful. you have to try several of them to be fair. just look at the kaggle datasets with tabular data and check which models are winning.

messages.text: if you really want a global solution, try simulated annealing which is probabilistic and not gradient-based. it is slow but is guaranteed to find the global optimum if done properly. probabilistic models too are many and as i have said, there is no single solution to different problems.

elements.text: if you really want a global solution, try simulated annealing which is probabilistic and not gradient-based. it is slow but is guaranteed to find the global optimum if done properly. probabilistic models too are many and as i have said, there is no single solution to different problems.

messages.text: <@UDGT4PM41> fair points but you already biased your choice of modeling to gradient-based solutions. if you look at all problems to be solvable by gradients, you might miss some that can be attacked better in a probabilistic way or by svm way, or by population-based way etc. it reminded me of the time when newton introduced calculus to the world and people began using integration and differentiation to almost all disciplines from social science to psychology to history etc. we have to be careful in applying one solution to all problems. we might miss some simpler solutions and declare that calculus is the answer to everything just because we did not try other simpler paradigm or approaches.

elements.text: fair points but you already biased your choice of modeling to gradient-based solutions. if you look at all problems to be solvable by gradients, you might miss some that can be attacked better in a probabilistic way or by svm way, or by population-based way etc. it reminded me of the time when newton introduced calculus to the world and people began using integration and differentiation to almost all disciplines from social science to psychology to history etc. we have to be careful in applying one solution to all problems. we might miss some simpler solutions and declare that calculus is the answer to everything just because we did not try other simpler paradigm or approaches.

messages.text: quantum idea which is probabilistic won’t happen if we just stick to single paradigm of newton calculus. this is what made einstein adamant about quantum idea because he is using much of calculus and biased about it instead of letting results of experiments influence his conclusion. God does not play dice only meant that God is not probabilistic but gradient-based ;) as what einstein thinks because he is a product of newtonian calculus. we are lucky that probability theory was invented independent of calculus or else we will be stuck with the calculus view of the world which is a good estimate but does not cover the other parts of reality.

messages.text:
attaching scientific machine learning to gradient-based approach is i think an oversimplification and will
miss other approaches in machine learning which are not based on calculus and can be optimal in some problems. as scientists, we should not put our biases and let experimentation and results rule our conclusions by trying different modeling approaches and paradigms.

messages.text: which make me think that julia should also develop or encourage development of quantum packages aside from calculus packages and probabilistic models because nobody knows what’s the optimal solution in the future. better not rely on one basket full of the same solutions. we need building blocks of solutions from different paradigms. it is understandable that there is bias right now towards calculus packages because julia has not attracted yet the kind of community that R has which are more on statistical and probabilistic MLs backgrounds and not just the gradient-based MLs.

messages.text: besides, there is that politics of publication where ML papers sound fancy and attractive if it is about deep learning at the expense that other paradigms get less attention. i remember the time when SVM just won all benchmarks vs ANN and people started to publish SVM and kernel trick themes and stopped development and investigations of ANN approaches. now, it’s ANN time at the expense of other paradigms.

messages.text: Quantum mechanics is a very special type of "discrete".  Hilbert spaces themselves are necessarily continuous, which is why differential equations are applicable to quantum mechanics (as demonstrated above).  Probably better to say that quantum mechanics is "continuous" rather than "discrete".  Theories with non-separable hilbert spaces (this means that the hilbert space has an uncountably infinite number of dimensions) take the concept of continuity to an almost absurd degree and by some measure they are more "continuous" than classical mechanics (i.e. the number of dimensions of a phase space is always parameterized by a discrete set, whereas in a quantum theory with a non-seperable hilbert space even the dimensions of the space the theory lives in must be parameterized continuously).

elements.text: Quantum mechanics is a very special type of "discrete".  Hilbert spaces themselves are necessarily continuous, which is why differential equations are applicable to quantum mechanics (as demonstrated above).  Probably better to say that quantum mechanics is "continuous" rather than "discrete".  Theories with non-separable hilbert spaces (this means that the hilbert space has an uncountably infinite number of dimensions) take the concept of continuity to an almost absurd degree and by some measure they are more "continuous" than classical mechanics (i.e. the number of dimensions of a phase space is always parameterized by a discrete set, whereas in a quantum theory with a non-seperable hilbert space even the dimensions of the space the theory lives in must be parameterized continuously).

messages.text: i think the paradigm is not about discrete vs continuous but whether the measurement can be done deterministically in newtonian mechanics vs probabilistically in quantum mechanics. probability allows jumps and many quantum weirdness while deterministic ones allow infinite fractions without jumps. what is considered as singularity in newtonian world is easily explained in probabilistic world. the cat being dead or alive is just simply a terrible way to use probability. they have to invent a new label called uncertainty principle instead of just calling it probabilistic and act as if they invented a new idea.

messages.text: well a very, very crucial point is that e.g. a quantum superposition of states is *NOT* the same as a classical probabiliyt distribution and can *NOT* be represented as such, it gives different results, see for example a description of the EPR paradox (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EPR_paradox>)

messages.text: for sure they can extend the classical theory of probability because the main core of the idea in probability is that things are not deterministic which is what newtonian physics assume. whether the behavior is localized or at a distance, the simple fact is that the entire behavior is stochastic and not deterministic. it only collapses to a single point of observation when the observer measures it which is basically what happens because measurement is imposing bias to a particular period in time and space when the observer decides to perform the observation.

attachments.title: Life on the Edge: The Coming of Age of Quantum Biology | Johnjoe Mcfadden
attachments.text: Life is the most extraordinary phenomenon in the known universe; but how does it work? Even in this age of cloning and synthetic biology, the remarkable truth remains: nobody has ever made anything living entirely out of dead material. Life remains the only way to make life. Are we missing a vital ingredient in its creation?

messages.text: so going back to the main reason of this thread, ML modeling is a guess of the mapping between  input and output. gradient-based approach is just one of the many heuristics in error minimization of actual and predicted values which we somehow associate to learning. model selection is critical because each problem will have different error surface and the heuristic that is optimal in one problem can be very suboptimal in another problem. my suggestion is always compare your chosen model with the baselines such as ensembles, svm, stochastic/probabilistic models, etc. i would even suggest to not select your model apriori but let the results of experiments be the driving force in choosing your model. of course if there are some constraints to consider, your choice of models can be smaller but always compare it with some baselines to have an idea how your preferred model performs relative to other models. if our target of ML modeling is to somehow develop a really intelligent system, perhaps we can ask whether our brain is using gradients or quantum computing to learn ;). my bet is we are doing some quantum learning similar to quantum computation in the photosynthesis in plants, magnetic compass of birds, and even in our sense of smell. quantum computing in living things are quiet ubiquitous and it won’t surprise me that intelligence and awareness is a product of quantum computing with gradients refinement.

messages.text: Let’s try a synthesis: yes, there is more to ML than deep neural networks with gradient descent, but there is also more to automatic differentiation and non-standard evaluation than DNNs with gradient descent. So being strong on that, Julia is in a good position, not only for machine learning, but also other types of sci modelling, inferential statistics, probabilistic programming etc.

messages.text: yeah. i think if we have more tools encompassing all the different techniques, it will be good because we can always use many of them to compare which one is the fittest model.

messages.text: the revival of deep learning or ANN is their good results in image datasets. for tabular datasets, the non-gradient approaches are still better such as ensembles, svms, and stochastic approaches. i think tabular datasets appear to have non-structured features in comparison to images that is why ANN/deep learning are less robust on tabular data. for images, other non-gradient approaches can be slower because we have no gpu-like support to these algos. on the other hand, without the gpu support to ANN, the same issue occurs also. to me, gradient-based approaches are the most difficult to optimize and its difficulty can be exposed if you use ANN in tabular data. the easiest to optimize are svm and ensembles. either they work or not. with ANN, it is highly sensitive to its initial parameters. this is just based on my experience. if you use deep learning or ANN in images, it is a no-brainer but not with tabular datasets.

messages.text:
My point was just that there's a ton of stuff that's just plain incorrect in what you're saying, but the high level view is correct. Let's leave it at <@U6C937ENB>’s summary and move on. This has gone past the point of silly and I will no longer be able to not resist trolling statements like "other non-gradient approaches can be slower because we have no gpu-like support to these algos". I got your point from the start (as someone developing alternative methods...), but saying that there's no GPU support for the alternative methods, of which you have previously mentioned XGBoost in that category, but there's:

<https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gpu/index.html>

a ton of GPU-based SVMs and other algorithms: <https://medium.com/analytics-vidhya/how-to-install-and-run-thundersvm-in-google-colab-de1fe49eef85>, <https://docs.rapids.ai/api/cuml/stable/>, <https://medium.com/rapids-ai/fast-support-vector-classification-with-rapids-cuml-6e49f4a7d89e>, etc. We know the point but let's not go too far.
